docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 4 CONTENTS OF STATEMENT OF CLAIM AND SUMMONS [rr 6.12–6.17]

heading.title: DIVISION 4 CONTENTS OF STATEMENT OF CLAIM AND SUMMONS [rr 6.12–6.17]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 4 CONTENTS OF STATEMENT OF CLAIM AND SUMMONS [rr 6.12–6.17]

leg:heading.title: CONTENTS OF STATEMENT OF CLAIM AND SUMMONS [rr 6.12–6.17]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.12] r 6.12 Relief claimed (cf SCR Part 7, rule 1; DCR Part 5, rules 6 and 6A; LCR Part 5, rules 1 and 2)

leg:heading.title: Relief claimed (cf SCR Part 7, rule 1; DCR Part 5, rules 6 and 6A; LCR Part 5, rules 1 and 2)

p.text: A statement of claim or summons must specifically state the relief claimed by the plaintiff.
If the relief claimed requires the determination or direction of the court on any question, the statement of claim or summons must state the question.
Costs referred to in section 329(1)(c) of the Legal Profession Act 2004 (costs payable for the enforcement of a lump sum debt or liquidated sum for damages) must be specifically claimed.
[subr (3) am Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[8], effective 8 December 2006]
Costs, other than those referred to in section 329(1)(c) of the Legal Profession Act 2004, need not be specifically claimed.
[subr (4) am Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[8], effective 8 December 2006]
Exemplary damages and aggravated compensatory damages must be specifically claimed.
An order for interest up to judgment must be specifically claimed.
In the case of a liquidated claim, a claim for an order for interest up to judgment:
must specify the period or periods for which interest is claimed, and
must specify the rate or rates at which interest is claimed.
If no rate of interest is specified under subrule (7)(b), the rate at which interest is claimed is taken to be:
in respect of the period from 1 January to 30 June in any year — the rate that is 4% above the cash rate last published by the Reserve Bank of Australia before that period commenced, and
in respect of the period from 1 July to 31 December in any year — the rate that is 4% above the cash rate last published by the Reserve Bank of Australia before that period commenced.
[subr (8) subst Amendment 33 of 2010 Sch 1[2], effective 1 July 2010]
See Part 46 as to the additional matters to be included in a summons relating to an appeal.
Legislation cited in [6.12.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 19, r 36.1, r 6.12(2).
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 22, s 56, 90.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 63.

The rule requires that originating process should generally specify the relief claimed in proceedings. In some instances, as r 6.12(2) recognises, where the claim involves the construction of a will, or the determination of a similar matter, the appropriate course to adopt, rather than setting out the particular result contended for, is to pose the various alternative questions that the court will be required to consider. In either case, CPA s 56 requires the court to facilitate the determine the real issues in dispute, and CPA ss 22 and 90 permit the court to “give such judgment as the nature of the case requires”. Those sections are complemented by UCPR r 36.1 , which permits the court “at any stage of the proceedings” to “give such judgment, or make such order, as the nature of the case requires, whether or not the claim for relief extending to that judgment or order is included in any statement of claim or summons”. And specific provisions in each court’s principal legislation (eg, s 63 of the Supreme Court Act 1970) may require the court to determine proceedings finally and to grant all the remedies to which the parties are entitled. Because of these various provisions, as well as the amplitude of the power of amendment in UCPR Pt 19 , it is generally correct to say that a party’s failure to claim a particular form of relief in the originating process will not necessarily disentitle it from obtaining an appropriate order. But it is clearly desirable that parties should be required to identify at the outset of the proceedings the nature of the relief that they claim. Doing so is both a matter of fairness to the opposing party, of assistance in identifying the real matters of contest and a matter of self interest in assisting the chances of compromise. Compliance with the requirements of the present rule is therefore a matter of importance.
Legislation cited in [6.12.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Liability Act 2002 s 21.
(NSW) Motor Accidents Act 1988 s 81A.
(NSW) Motor Accidents Compensation Act 1999 s 144.
(NSW) Workers Compensation Act 1987 s 151R.
(NSW) Defamation Act 1974 s 37.

Aggravated damages are awarded to compensate for the additional loss or damage resulting from the manner in which the defendant acted: New South Wales v Ibbett (2006) 231 ALR 485; 81 ALJR 427; [2006] HCA 57 at [31] and [34]; BC200610288 . Exemplary damages can only be awarded where a plaintiff otherwise has an accrued cause of action that entitles them to ordinary damages: see Watkins v Home Secretary [2006] 2 AC 807 (claim for misfeasance in public office — not actionable without proof of material damage). But exemplary damages are not themselves compensatory. They are awarded by way of punishment and for the purpose of deterrence: Uren v John Fairfax & Sons Pty Ltd (1966) 117 CLR 118 per Windeyer J at 149; [1967] ALR 25 . While the power to award exemplary damages is clear, its exercise is appropriately reserved for exceptional cases: Uren v John Fairfax & Sons Pty Ltd , above, at CLR 120, 149; Whitfield v De Lauret & Co Ltd (1920) 29 CLR 71 at 77, 81; 27 ALR 249 ; Australian Consolidated Press Ltd v Uren (1969) 117 CLR 221 at 239; [1969] 1 AC 590 at 642; BC6600050 ; XL Petroleum (NSW) Pty Ltd v Caltex Oil (Aust) Pty Ltd (1985) 155 CLR 448; 57 ALR 639 ; Lamb v Cotogno (1987) 164 CLR 1; 74 ALR 188 (exemplary damages awarded even against a defendant who was insured); Trend Management Ltd v Borg (1996) 40 NSWLR 500; BC9605704 ; Vignoli v Sydney Harbour Casino (2000) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-541; [1999] NSWSC 1113; BC9907659 (casino patron wrongfully detained on account of alleged overpayment); Venus Adult Shops Pty Ltd v Fraserside Holdings Ltd (2006) 70 IPR 517; [2006] FCAFC 188; BC200610704 at [156] (systematic breach of copyright for commercial purposes — exemplary damages refused); New South Wales v Ibbett (2006) 231 ALR 485; 81 ALJR 427; [2006] HCA 57 at [38]; BC200610288 (police trespass on land and threat with firearm — exemplary damages awarded) and see generally “Tort and Punishment — Exemplary Damages” (1996) 70 ALJ 47. Exemplary damages may not be awarded if the defendant has already been dealt with under the criminal law: Gray v Motor Accident Commission (1998) 196 CLR 1; 158 ALR 485; [1998] HCA 70; BC9806067 . Claims for exemplary damages have been abolished in personal injury cases involving negligence, in industrial accident cases and in defamation: Civil Liability Act 2002 s 21 ; Motor Accidents Act 1988 s 81A ; Motor Accidents Compensation Act 1999 s 144 ; Workers Compensation Act 1987 s 151R ; Defamation Act 2005 s 37 .
Legislation cited in [6.12.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Sch 1.

This rule does not apply to proceedings in class 1 (environmental planning and protection appeals), 2 (local government and miscellaneous appeals and applications) or 3 (land tenure, valuation, ratings and compensation matters) of the Land and Environment Court: see Sch 1 to UCPR. It does apply to proceedings in class 4 (environmental planning and protection and development contract civil enforcement) of the Land and Environment Court: see also Sch 1 of the UCPR.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.12A] r 6.12A Proceedings for order in the nature of prerogative writ

leg:heading.title: Proceedings for order in the nature of prerogative writ

p.text: [r 6.12A rep Amendment 58 of 2013 Sch 1[2], effective 15 March 2013]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.13] r 6.13 Notice to defendant in statement of claim (cf SCR Part 7, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Notice to defendant in statement of claim (cf SCR Part 7, rule 3)

p.text: A statement of claim:
must state that, unless a defence is filed in the registry, the proceedings may result in a judgment or order against the defendant, and
must give the address of the registry where the statement of claim is filed (which will consequently be the address where any further pleadings and other documents are to be filed), and
must specify the time limited by these rules for filing a defence.
See rule 6.8 in relation to claims for the possession of land.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.14] r 6.14 Notice to defendant in summons (cf SCR Part 7, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Notice to defendant in summons (cf SCR Part 7, rule 3)

p.text: A summons filed in proceedings in which there is a defendant:
must state that:
the proceedings may be heard, and

the defendant is liable to suffer judgment or an order against the defendant, unless there is attendance before the court by the defendant or his or her barrister or solicitor at the time and place stated in the summons, and
must further state that, before any such attendance, the defendant must file a notice of appearance in the registry, and
must give the address of the registry at the place named as the place for attendance.

Generally speaking, so long as the proposed return day complies with the period of notice or service required by the rules, a party is entitled to obtain the earliest return day on which, according to the court’s ordinary procedures, matters of that kind would be dealt with. If conflict arises on this issue between the filing party and the registry staff, the appropriate course to adopt is to approach either a registrar/deputy registrar or the relevant judge’s associate so that an appropriate return date endorsement can me made on the document to be filed. This procedure does not involve any abridgment of time in the strict sense and it is not necessary for any formal application for abridgment to be made.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.15] r 6.15 Summons to specify return day (cf SCR Part 5, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Summons to specify return day (cf SCR Part 5, rule 3)

p.text: A summons must state a return day.
The return day may be fixed by the court or, if not fixed by the court, is to be obtained from the registry.
If there is a defendant, the summons is to be served on the defendant not less than 5 days before the return day unless the court orders otherwise.
A summons is to bear a note stating the terms of any order made under subrule (3).
If a return day is obtained from the registry and the summons is to be served outside New South Wales, the return day is to be not less than one month after the date of filing of the summons.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.16] r 6.16 Alteration of return day in summons (cf SCR Part 5, rule 5A)

leg:heading.title: Alteration of return day in summons (cf SCR Part 5, rule 5A)

p.text: The court may, by notice given to the parties by telephone or otherwise, postpone the return day for a summons to a later day, and may authorise the parties’ solicitors to make corresponding alterations to the copies of the summonses held by them.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.17] r 6.17 Payment towards liquidated claim stays proceedings on claim (cf SCR Part 7, rule 4; DCR Part 14, rule 2; LCR Part 12, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Payment towards liquidated claim stays proceedings on claim (cf SCR Part 7, rule 4; DCR Part 14, rule 2; LCR Part 12, rule 2)

p.text: This rule applies to proceedings in which the plaintiff makes a liquidated claim, but makes no claim of any other kind.
The defendant in any such proceedings may, within the time limited for appearance, pay to the plaintiff the sum of:
the amount claimed (other than costs), including any interest claimed, and
an amount for costs equal to the amount fixed in relation to such a claim by the regulations under the Legal Profession Act 2004 , and
if the amount so fixed does not include the fee paid on filing the originating process, an amount equal to that fee.
[subr (2) am Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[9], effective 8 December 2006]
Having made such a payment, the defendant may file a notice of payment.
The filing of a notice of payment operates as a permanent stay of the proceedings unless the court orders otherwise.
A statement of claim commencing proceedings to which this rule applies must bear a note to the effect of this rule and must specify the amounts for costs referred to in subrule (2)(b) and (c).
The approved form for Notice of payment is Form 34.

level.toc-caption: [6.17.5] Stay of claim for liquidated demand

p.text: Legislation cited in [6.17.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 14.25, r 20.34, r 29.7.

heading.title: Stay of claim for liquidated demand

p.text: The stay provided for in the present rule operates only the defendant filing notice of payment. The rule complements the defence of tender provided for in r 14.25 . Under that rule a defendant who tendered the amount claimed before the commencement of proceedings may obtain a stay of the proceedings by paying the money into court. The present rule is also complemented by r 20.34 , which permits a defendant to consent to judgment on a liquidated claim in the whole of the amount claimed. Under r 29.7 a plaintiff may also obtain judgment for the amount claimed where a defendant fails to appear at the hearing of trial in relation to a liquidated claim.

In the appropriate case, the court may lift the stay that operates by virtue of this rule. See Lambert v Mainland Market Deliveries Ltd [1977] 2 All ER 826; [1977] 1 WLR 825 (insured’s personal claim originally limited to uninsured loss, subsequent claim by subrogated insurer for the full amount, stay removed).
